item.title: Congo, Rwanda Sign US-Backed Peace Deal to End Years of War
item.description: The Democratic Republic of Congo and Rwanda agreed to a US-backed peace deal meant to end years of deadly conflict and promote development in Congo’s volatile eastern region.
item.dc:creator: Michael J Kavanagh

media:content.media:description: Rwanda’s Nduhungirehe, from left, Rubio and Democratic Republic of the Congo’s Kayikwamba during a signing ceremony at the State Department

item.title: Big Banks Pass Fed’s Stress Test, Setting Stage for Payouts
item.description: A group of large US banks comfortably cleared the Federal Reserve’s annual stress test, setting the stage for lenders to boost buybacks and dividends for shareholders.
item.dc:creator: Yash Roy, Katanga Johnson

media:content.media:description: Buildings in the financial district of Manhattan.

item.title: Bessent Plays Down Speculation of Any Early Trump Fed Chair Pick
item.description: Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent played down speculation that President Donald Trump may consider an early move to nominate a successor to Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell, pointing to one potential timeline that could see a name emerge in October or November.
item.dc:creator: Daniel Flatley

media:content.media:description: US secretary of the treasury Scott Bessent speaks to members of the media after a Senate Republican policy luncheon at the US Capitol in Washington, DC, on June 27.

item.title: Trump Stresses July Tariff Threat, Bessent Teases Extension
item.description: President Donald Trump hardened his threat to raise tariffs on certain countries by his July 9 deadline, while Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent signaled there may be some extensions to wrap up major pacts by the Labor Day holiday.
item.dc:creator: Stephanie Lai, Daniel Flatley

media:content.media:description: Scott Bessent

item.title: Romanian Leader Pledges More Budget Measures to Curb Deficit
item.description: Romania’s premier outlined fresh measures to cut the ballooning budget deficit as the new government seeks to safeguard the country’s investment-grade rating and ease investor concern.
item.dc:creator: Andra Timu

media:content.media:description: Designated Prime Minister Ilie Bolojan gives a joint press statement with the Romanian President at Cotroceni Palace, the Romanian Presidency's headquarters, in Bucharest June 20, 2025.

item.title: US Regulators Says Comments on Key Bank Capital Rule Due Aug. 26
item.description: The US Federal Reserve and other bank regulators set an Aug. 26 deadline for public comments on a proposal to ease a key bank capital rule, saying they expect the amount of overall capital that big lenders would maintain as a result of their plan would “generally stay the same.”
item.dc:creator: Megan Howard

media:content.media:description: The Marriner S. Eccles Federal Reserve building in Washington, DC.

item.title: Economists Raise Growth Outlook for Canada as Tariff Threats Ease
item.description: Analysts boosted their forecasts for economic growth in Canada this year as fears of a drawn-out trade dispute with the US fade.
item.dc:creator: Erik Hertzberg, Dana Morgan

media:content.media:description: Trucks cross the Peace Bridge at the Canada-US border in Fort Erie, Ontario, Canada, on Wednesday, April 2, 2025. US President Trump on April 2 plans to roll out tariffs on global trading partners, the centerpiece of his effort to bring back manufacturing to the US and reshape a world trade system he has long decried as unfair.

item.title: Merz Tells EU Leaders to Beware Growing Dangers of a Debt Crisis
item.description: German Chancellor Friedrich Merz warned European Union leaders that the mounting debts of governments and companies are fueling the risk of a new financial crisis.
item.dc:creator: Arne Delfs, Jorge Valero, Alberto Nardelli

media:content.media:description: Germany's chancellor Friedrich Merz

item.title: US Consumer Spending Drops in May, Price Pressures Remain Muted
item.description: US consumer spending declined in May by the most since the start of the year, indicating elevated uncertainty around the Trump administration’s economic policies is increasingly weighing on the outlook for growth.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Boesler

media:content.media:description: Shoppers in Palm Beach, Florida.

item.title: US Consumer Sentiment Climbs as Inflation Expectations Improve
item.description: US consumer sentiment rose sharply in June to a four-month high and inflation expectations improved notably as concerns eased about the economic outlook and personal finances.
item.dc:creator: Nazmul Ahasan

media:content.media:description: Shoppers inside a Home Depot store in Roseville, California.

item.title: East African Countries Face Broad Crackdown on Political Dissent
item.description: When thousands of young Kenyans converged across the nation this week to mark a year since scores of them were killed in protests, police were ready and opened fire, leaving at least 16 dead.
item.dc:creator: David Herbling

media:content.media:description: Protesters hold Kenyan flags during a demonstration in Nairobi on June 25. Photographer: Gerald Anderson/Anadolu/Getty Images

item.title: Iceland’s Inflation Accelerates Again, Fueled by Airfares
item.description: Iceland’s inflation unexpectedly picked up for the second month in three, damping expectations for further easing by the Atlantic nation’s central bank.
item.dc:creator: Ott Ummelas

item.title: Canada Economy Set for Contraction in Second Quarter
item.description: The Canadian economy is on track for a modest decline this quarter, yet isn’t deteriorating as fast as some economists feared.
item.dc:creator: Randy Thanthong-Knight

media:content.media:description: An employee assembles a rear bumper an auto parts manufacturing facility in Guelph, Ontario.

item.title: UK Budget Reversals Threaten Reeves as Well as Her Fiscal Rules
item.description: Labour’s costly climbdowns on big policy plans don’t just leave Chancellor of the Exchequer Rachel Reeves with the dilemma of how to find the money to meet her budget rules. They’re also starting to raise questions about her own job security.
item.dc:creator: Philip Aldrick, Joe Mayes, Freya Jones

media:content.media:description: Rachel Reeves and Keir Starmer on June 23. Photographer: Jacob King/AFP/Getty Images

item.title: Turkey Set to Skip Minimum-Wage Hike in Boost for Investors
item.description: Turkey’s government plans to skip a mid-year increase in the minimum wage, according to people with knowledge of the matter, resisting political pressure to alleviate rising living costs.
item.dc:creator: Firat Kozok, Beril Akman

media:content.media:description: Workers clean the floor of a self service cafe area in Ankara, Turkey, on Monday, on June 26, 2023. The Turkish lira has depreciated by nearly 18% against the dollar this month.

item.title: India Posts Current Account Surplus as Trade Gap Narrows
item.description: India’s current account returned a better than expected surplus in the January-March quarter as trade deficit narrowed following the revision of gold import data.
item.dc:creator: Anup Roy

media:content.media:description: Gantry cranes load a container ship at the Mundra Port in Mundra, India.

item.title: Spanish Economy Minister Cuerpo Runs for Eurogroup President
item.description: Spanish Economy Minister Carlos Cuerpo is running to head the Eurogroup, saying global developments require new leadership of the gatherings of euro-zone finance ministers.
item.dc:creator: Daniel Basteiro

media:content.media:description: Carlos Cuerpo ahead of a Eurogroup meeting in Brussels. Photographer: Simon Wohlfahrt/Bloomberg

item.title: Warning Signs of Weak Job Creation in the US
item.description: I’m Mark Niquette, a US economy reporter in Columbus. Today we’re looking at the US labor market. Send us feedback and tips to ecodaily@bloomberg.net. And if you aren’t yet signed up to receive this newsletter, you can do so here.
item.dc:creator: Mark Niquette

item.title: Fed’s Kashkari Sees Two Rate Cuts This Year Amid Tariff Unknowns
item.description: Federal Reserve Bank of Minneapolis President Neel Kashkari said he sees two interest-rate cuts as likely this year — with the first potentially in September — but warned that tariffs could have a delayed impact on inflation and policymakers should remain flexible.
item.dc:creator: Catarina Saraiva

media:content.media:description: Minneapolis Fed President Neel Kashkari.

item.title: China’s Central Bank Says Economy Is on Positive Track But Challenges Persist
item.description: China’s economy is showing positive signs and confidence is building, but challenges such as insufficient domestic demand and deflationary pressure persist, according to the country’s central bank.
item.dc:creator: Foster Wong

media:content.media:description: Pedestrians pass stalls in Kunming, China, on Monday, June 16, 2025. China's unexpectedly strong retail sales in May gave the economy some relief from US tariffs, although the momentum may not last as deflationary forces persist and a housing market slump shows signs of deepening.

item.title: Thai Finance Minister Heads to US for Trade Talks Next Week
item.description: Thai Finance Minister Pichai Chunhavajira will visit the US next week for tariff negotiations in an attempt to clinch a trade deal ahead of Washington’s deadline on July 9.
item.dc:creator: Pathom Sangwongwanich

media:content.media:description: Pichai Chunhavajira Photographer: Valeria Mongelli/Bloomberg

item.title: Chile Central Bank Policymaker Sees Good Omens After Long Inflation Fight
item.description: Chile’s central bank sees a set of factors coming together that will help bring inflation back down to target early in 2026, board member Luis Felipe Cespedes said in an interview.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Malinowski

media:content.media:description: Luis Felipe Cespedes, board member of the Central Bank of Chile, speaks during an interview at the bank headquarters in Santiago, Chile

item.title: French, Spanish Prices Tick Up But Not Enough to Worry ECB
item.description: Inflation inched up in France and Spain but not enough to concern European Central Bank officials who are optimistic that their 2% target will be met sustainably this year.
item.dc:creator: William Horobin

media:content.media:description: France’s uptick was driven by services, where inflation climbed to 2.4% from 2.1% in May. Photographer: Jeremy Suyker/Bloomberg

item.title: Lots More on What’s Going On in Iran’s Markets (Podcast)
item.description: Iran is a huge country with a sizable stock market. And yet, years of sanctions and other restrictions mean it’s tough to even look up its stock prices (much less invest there.) In this episode, we catch up with Maciej Wojtal, CEO and CIO of AmtelonCapital, an Amsterdam-based fund that specializes in Iranian stocks. item.dc:creator: Tracy Alloway, Joe Weisenthal

item.title: Starmer’s Latest U-Turn Risks £3 Billion Hit and More Tax Rises
item.description: Keir Starmer backed down to a rebellion within his own Labour party over a planned £5 billion ($6.9 billion) cut to disability entitlements, in a costly U-Turn that dents his authority and leaves his chancellor struggling to avoid tax hikes.
item.dc:creator: Irina Anghel, Alex Wickham, Ailbhe Rea

media:content.media:description: Keir Starmer attends the British Chambers of Commerce conference in London on June 26.

item.title: Thai Central Bank Vows to Step In If Baht Moves Are Unhinged
item.description: Thailand’s central bank is ready to tackle excessive baht volatility by managing any moves “unhinged” from its fundamentals, a deputy governor said, amid calls from local businesses to temper the currency’s rally to help exports and tourism.
item.dc:creator: Suttinee Yuvejwattana, Thomas Kutty Abraham

item.title: ECB May Need to Hold Rates Amid ‘Two-Sided’ Risks, Knot Tells FT
item.description: The European Central Bank may have to keep borrowing costs steady for the forseeable future as officials confront both upside and downside risks to consumer prices, Governing Council member Klaas Knot said.
item.dc:creator: Mark Schroers

media:content.media:description: Klaas Knot, president of De Nederlandsche Bank NV, during the Globalisation and Geo-Economic Fragmentation conference, in Amsterdam, Netherlands, on Wednesday, April 9, 2025. Bruegel's conference gathers leading experts and policymakers and is part of the think tank's 20th anniversary events program. Photographer: Lina Selg/Bloomberg

item.title: Lee Starts Term With 64% Rating on South Korea Recovery Optimism
item.description: South Korea’s new President Lee Jae Myung started his presidency with a higher approval rating than recent predecessors, as hopes for an economic recovery rise after months of political turbulence.
item.dc:creator: Soo-Hyang Choi

media:content.media:description: Lee Jae Myung shakes hands with lawmakers at the National Assembly in Seoul on June 26. Photographer: SeongJoon Cho/Bloomberg

item.title: Ireland’s Firms Brace for Economic Hit With Quiet Confidence
item.description: Hundreds of companies, 200,000 jobs, billions of euro in corporation tax revenue. Add it all up and Ireland’s reliance on US investment for its economic success is starkly clear.
item.dc:creator: Jennifer Duggan

media:content.media:description: Paschal Donohoe at the Future of Finance in Dublin. Photographer: Dean O'Brien/Bloomberg

item.title: Thai Rate Pause Is Lifeline Saved for Turbulence Ahead, BOT Says
item.description: The Bank of Thailand’s decision to leave borrowing costs unchanged this week gives it a “monetary lifeline” to deal with challenges ranging from US tariffs and geopolitical tensions to domestic politics, according to Deputy Governor Piti Disyatat.
item.dc:creator: Suttinee Yuvejwattana, Thomas Kutty Abraham
